item.title: Coronation Live Updates: Charles III Is Crowned King
item.description: Charles, Britain’s first new monarch in 70 years, was crowned at Westminster Abbey in London during an ancient ceremony that incorporated some modern touches. “I come not to be served, but to serve,” he said.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Faces Pressure Over Counteroffensive, as Putin Bides His Time
item.description: Ukraine is feeling short-term pressure from its Western backers for success in a looming counteroffensive. Vladimir Putin seems to be operating on a longer timeline.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops training at a firing range in the Zaporizhzhia region last month.

item.title: Warring Parties in Sudan to Hold Talks in Saudi Arabia
item.description: American officials say they hope representatives of two rival Sudanese generals will agree to an enduring cease-fire and to allow humanitarian aid into the country.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: People evacuated from Sudan arriving at the port in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on Thursday.

item.title: Car Bombing Injures Russian Nationalist Prilepin, State Media Reports
item.description: Zakhar Prilepin, who himself fought in eastern Ukraine, has long advocated an imperialist foreign policy by Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Zakhar Prilepin in 2012.

item.title: Ukraine Claims It Shot Down Russia’s Most Sophisticated Missile for First Time
item.description: The air force said it intercepted the hypersonic missile with a newly delivered U.S.-made Patriot air-defense battery. U.S. officials confirmed the strike.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian firefighters and police officers in Kyiv inspecting a piece of debris, thought to be from a missile or drone, on Thursday.

item.title: More than 13,000 Evacuated as Wildfires Burn in Western Canada
item.description: Over 100 wildfires were burning across Alberta on Saturday morning. Conditions conducive to fires were also expected in the U.S. Southwest over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Smoke rises from a wildfire near Lodgepole, Alberta, on Thursday.

item.title: How 2 Students Rescued Dozens of People from the Fighting in Sudan
item.description: As feuding generals turned the Sudanese capital into a war zone, two university students navigated a battered Toyota through the chaos and saved at least 60 desperate people.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh

item.title: Serbian Shooting Claims 8 Lives, Day After School Massacre Killed 9
item.description: A day after Serbia’s first mass shooting in seven years, a second one left the small country in shock and its president called for a radical reduction in gun ownership.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut, John Yoon, Joe Orovic and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer on Friday stood guard in Dubona, Serbia, following a mass shooting in the area south of Belgrade that started Thursday night.

item.title: The Dnipro River, Axis of Life and Death in Ukraine
item.description: The river has helped to define Ukraine’s history and culture, and remains vital to daily sustenance, even as it also serves as a front line in war — as it has countless times over thousands of years.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung and Marc Santora
item.media:description: Getting ready to plunge into the water of the Dnipro River to mark the Orthodox Christian feast of Epiphany in Dnipro.

item.title: Iran Targets Businesses to Stop Women From Ignoring Hijab Law
item.description: As more Iranian women go without the head scarves mandated by law, efforts by the government to force businesses to promote compliance points to a growing struggle in the months ahead.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Women in the Iranian capital, Tehran, last month. Since mass protests broke out last fall, more women are refusing to abide by Iran’s hijab law.

item.title: What’s Behind Serbia’s Gun Violence
item.description: Serbia has one of the highest rates of gun ownership in the world, after the Balkan wars left the country awash in weapons.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers patrolling the village of Dubona, Serbia, on Friday, after the country’s second mass shooting occurred in less than a week.

item.title: Why So Many Nations in the King’s Realm Want to Say Goodbye
item.description: Whether through a hard break or a soft fade in ties, nations that have kept the British monarch as their head of state are moving toward separation.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: A broadcast showing King Charles III at a pub in Sydney, Australia, last year.

item.title: He’s 86 and Long Retired. Why Are Israelis Protesting Outside His Home?
item.description: Years ago, Aharon Barak helped shape Israel’s judicial system. Now the government wants to unravel his legacy, thrusting the retiree back into the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aharon Barak in his home office in Tel Aviv on Sunday.

item.title: As a King Is Crowned, Some Britons Ask Why the Monarchy Persists
item.description: As long as there has been a monarchy, there have been questions about its legitimacy. But for many people, it would be difficult to disentangle the royal family from British identity.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Union Jacks in London in April. One constant of the British monarchy has been the calls for its abolition.

item.title: Were William and Kate Late to the Coronation?
item.description: The Prince and Princess of Wales arrived at Westminster Abbey after King Charles III, prompting speculation among the many journalists covering the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince William and Catherine, Princess of Wales, leaving after the coronation ceremony for King Charles III and Queen Camilla in London.

item.title: At the Coronation, Harry and William Find Themselves Rows Apart
item.description: The sons of King Charles III did not appear to interact during their father’s coronation.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince Harry, center, at Westminster Abbey on Saturday, when he had a less prominent role than other members of the royal family.

item.title: Serbia Mourns and Reflects After Mass Shootings
item.description: Back-to-back massacres have forced the country, still in mourning, to grapple with its complicated and long gun tradition.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Vladimir Zivojinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral on Saturday in a village south of Belgrade, Serbia, for some of the victims of a shooting days earlier.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Ethnic Clashes in India’s Manipur State
item.description: Violence erupted over a question of who gets to claim special tribal status.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A truck burns on Thursday in Imphal, the capital of Manipur state, where there have been days of violence between rival ethnic groups.

item.title: In Australia, He Was a ‘Great Father.’ Secretly, He Was an Escaped Convict.
item.description: New DNA evidence helped confirm that a man who went by John Damon and died in Australia in 2010 was actually William Leslie Arnold, a convicted killer and escaped inmate from Nebraska.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez

item.title: What Happened at King Charles’s Coronation: Key Moments
item.description: The lavish ceremony for Britain’s first new reigning monarch in 70 years, was brimming with ancient traditions with a few modern touches.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla waved to the crowd from the balcony at Buckingham Palace, after the coronation, on Saturday.

item.title: The Coronation of King Charles III, in Photos
item.description: As Britain’s King Charles III is crowned, here’s a selection of the best photographs from the coronation weekend.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla waving from the balcony of Buckingham Palace after they were crowned on Saturday.

item.title: Map: King Charles’s Coronation Procession Route
item.description: His route is markedly shorter than the one taken by Queen Elizabeth II in 1953.
item.dc:creator: Lazaro Gamio

item.title: Gordon Lightfoot’s Death Is a Loss That Feels Personal
item.description: Lightfoot’s music created the soundtrack for the daily life of many Canadian families.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Richer
item.media:description: Nature and wilderness were central themes of Gordon Lightfoot’s music.

item.title: It’s Coronation Day
item.description: Come for the crown jewels and gold stagecoach; stay for the questions about the monarchy’s relevance.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Canadians Greet King Charles’s Coronation With Muted Response
item.description: The king’s representative in Canada, where he is head of state, recently appealed to people in the country to “give him a chance.”
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III with Mary Simon, center, Canada’s governor general, and Indigenous leaders during an audience at Buckingham Palace in London on Thursday.

item.title: Share Your Thoughts on the Crowning of King Charles III
item.description: The New York Times invites readers to share their comments and observations about the coronation of Britain’s King Charles III.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Anti-Monarchists Protest Charles’s Coronation
item.description: Supporters of an elected head of state for Britain see the coronation as an opportunity to highlight the absurdity of having a royal family in the 21st century.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police led away demonstrators holding anti-monarchy signs before the royal procession began on the Mall in London on Saturday.

item.title: King Charles’s Coronation: Key Timings and What Will Happen
item.description: After the coronation service at Westminster Abbey, King Charles III and other members of the royal family will make an appearance on the balcony of Buckingham Palace.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Charles III was crowned king during a ceremony at Westminster Abbey in London on Saturday.

item.title: Your Coronation Briefing
item.description: A special edition on King Charles III.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

item.title: Russian Unease Over Ukraine War Grows Amid Attacks and Leadership Rifts
item.description: With a Ukrainian offensive looming, explosions in Crimea and inside Russia have rattled Moscow, sparking bureaucratic infighting among military commanders.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on the western outskirts of Bakhmut in April. Ukraine has fought for control over the city for months against Russia and Wagner mercenaries.

item.title: They refused to fight for Russia. The law did not treat them kindly.
item.description: Since Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, hundreds of Russian men have faced criminal charges for becoming war refuseniks. That has not stopped others from going to unusual lengths to avoid battle.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar

item.title: How Could AI Change War? U.S. Defense Experts Warn About New Tech
item.description: U.S. national security officials are warning about the potential for the new technology to upend war, cyber conflict and — in the most extreme case — the use of nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: “If we stop, guess who’s not going to stop: potential adversaries overseas,” the Pentagon’s chief information officer, John Sherman, said on Wednesday.

item.title: Yevgeny Prigozhin Becomes a Player in Russia After Years in the Shadows
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin has used his leadership of the Wagner mercenary force and social media to turn brutality into a personal brand.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, center, founder of the Wagner mercenary group, in Moscow last month.

item.title: Jill Biden Greets Children and Veterans in London Ahead of King Charles Coronation
item.description: Dr. Biden attended several events on Friday with Akshata Murty, the wife of Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Jill Biden, the first lady, and Akshata Murty, the wife of Britain’s prime minister, visiting the Charles Dickens Primary School on Friday.

item.title: What I’m Reading: Coronation Edition
item.description: Royal bodies, royal traitors
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trafalgar Square in London on Friday.

item.title: Palestinians Demand Israel Hand Over Body of Prominent Prisoner
item.description: Israel’s refusal to hand over the remains of Khader Adnan has drawn scrutiny of the country’s practice of keeping bodies as leverage to bargain for Israeli remains.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Relatives mourning in the West Bank village of Arraba on Tuesday after the death of Khader Adnan, a prominent Palestinian prisoner held by Israel.

item.title: Ferdinand Habsburg Would Have Been King. Instead He’s a Racecar Driver.
item.description: If the Austro-Hungarian Empire still existed, 25-year-old Ferdinand Habsburg would eventually be its ruler. Instead he’s a racecar driver.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Lisa Edi for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m so proud of my family and what they’ve done,” said Ferdinand Habsburg, the heir apparent to the House of Habsburg-Lorraine. “But I get to live a different life.”

item.title: Where Should a King Sit? A 700-Year-Old Chair Will Do.
item.description: The Coronation Chair, on which King Charles III will sit for part of his ceremony on Saturday, is getting a touch-up. It hasn’t been used since Queen Elizabeth II’s coronation in 1953.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Kirsty O'Connor/PA Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Coronation Chair, at Westminster Abbey in London, is being restored before the coronation of King Charles III on Saturday.

item.title: W.H.O. Ends Covid World Health Emergency Designation
item.description: The decision has little practical effect but is a significant moment in the struggle against a virus that has killed millions and upended lives throughout the world.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the W.H.O. director general, in Geneva last month.

item.title: Queen Camilla and the Triumph of Image Transformation
item.description: After the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, there was a sense among many in Britain that “We can’t have Camilla.” But a successful branding overhaul has brought her a significant mark of acceptance.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Camilla, Queen Consort of the United Kingdom
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Camilla, the wife of King Charles III, will be crowned as queen on Saturday.

item.title: Iraqi Man Accused of War Crimes Is Arrested in Belgium
item.description: The man is believed to have been part of a Qaeda terrorist cell that was partly responsible for bombings that killed at least 376 people in Iraq in 2009 and 2010.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Bombings in August 2009 near government ministries in Baghdad left at least 95 people dead.

item.title: Get Ready to See More of the Northern Lights
item.description: Over the past few months, viewings of the lights have increased in areas farther south than usual. That’s going to continue into 2025.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:description: The Northern lights above Fairbanks, Alaska, in December.

item.title: Ukraine wants to push forward. Black, soupy mud is making that difficult.
item.description: The unusually wet ground is one obstacle that the Ukrainian military, for all of its ingenuity, is finding difficult to overcome as it prepares for a counteroffensive against Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier from Ukraine’s 43rd Separate Artillery Brigade jumps down from a Panzerhaubitze, a German-made self-propelled howitzer, in a forest near the front line in Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: Russian and Ukrainian Delegates Fight Over Ukrainian Flag at a Conference
item.description: Two altercations over Ukrainian flags occurred at a regional parliamentary conference in Ankara, the Turkish capital.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd

item.title: ‘A Nightmare’
item.description: We explain the background of the military conflict in Sudan.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Khartoum on Wednesday.

item.title: Prince Harry Is Attending the Coronation, but Meghan and Their Children Aren’t
item.description: After years of family tensions, Prince Harry will attend his father’s coronation. But Harry’s wife, the Duchess of Sussex, is staying home in California with the couple’s children, Archie and Lilibet.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, in London last year during Queen Elizabeth II’s Platinum Jubilee.

item.title: Who’s Attending the Coronation: Royals, Jill Biden, Lionel Richie, Nick Cave and More
item.description: Royals from Europe and Asia plan to be there, as do Joanna Lumley and Nick Cave. President Biden does not.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Charles II, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Jordan Pettitt/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rehearsal for the coronation procession Wednesday morning near Buckingham Palace in central London.

item.title: Schedule of Events for King Charles III Coronation Weekend
item.description: Three days of official festivities include the crowning of Charles and Camilla on Saturday, lunches and a concert on Sunday and volunteering on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Flags commemorating the coronation of King Charles III at a street stall near Westminster Hall in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Indian Olympians Persist in Demanding Arrest of Wrestling Chief
item.description: Athletes vow to continue a protest after a clash with the police, saying politicians are covering for an official accused of sexually harassing female wrestlers.
item.dc:creator: Hari Kumar and Alex Travelli
item.media:description: The Indian wrestlers Vinesh Phogat, Bajrang Punia and Sakshi Malik last month during a sit-in protest in New Delhi.

item.title: England’s Local Elections Test Rishi Sunak’s Popularity
item.description: The Labour Party scored several significant victories in Conservative strongholds in votes viewed as a test of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s popularity.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Election workers counting votes in Stoke-on-Trent, England, on Friday.

item.title: Australia vs. Warner Bros.?
item.description: The newest A.F.L. team will be in Tasmania. Can the club can be named after the island’s resident marsupial, the Tasmanian devil?
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Michael Willson/Australian Football League, via Getty Images
item.media:description: At the announcement on Wednesday that Tasmania will soon be getting its own Australian Football League team.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: A Coronation Preview
item.description: Also, foreign business fears grow in China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A man attaches a flag commemorating the coronation of King Charles III outside Westminster Hall in London on Wednesday.

item.title: South Africa Allowed Russian Plane Under U.S. Sanctions to Land at Base
item.description: The move could increase tensions between South Africa and the United States as it moves to isolate Moscow over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
item.media:credit: Lee Warren/Gallo Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Waterkloof Air Force Base near Pretoria, South Africa, in 2020.

item.title: W.H.O. Dismisses Covid Origins Investigator for Sexual Misconduct
item.description: Peter K. Ben Embarek led a contentious international investigation into the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:description: Peter K. Ben Embarek, a Danish food safety scientist and member of the W.H.O. team tasked with investigating the origins of the coronavirus disease, at a news conference in Wuhan in 2021.

item.title: Sudanese Refugees Desperate for Safety Flee to Egypt
item.description: The war between two generals for power in Sudan has separated family members and driven tens of thousands to flee. Many had returned after the 2019 revolution with hopes for a more democratic future.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Heba Khamis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mawahib Mohammed and her family on their way to the train station in Aswan, Egypt, on Wednesday to travel to Cairo.

item.title: 8 Killed in Pakistan Shootings, Including 6 Teachers
item.description: No group claimed responsibility for the attacks, near the Afghan border. The authorities said they believed there was a sectarian dimension to the violence.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood and Zia ur-Rehman
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: People loading a teacher’s body into an ambulance on Thursday after a shooting inside a school in Parachinar, Pakistan.

item.title: Truth is Elusive in Kremlin Explosions
item.description: Kyiv and Moscow angrily blamed each other after two explosions in an apparent drone attack on the heart of Russian power, but whose outrage is real?
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: The Senate Palace within the Kremlin wall in Moscow on Wednesday, after two drones exploded near its dome in the early hours of the morning.

item.title: King Charles: A Life in Photos
item.description: Cameras have followed Britain’s new head of state since infancy. Here is a selection of memorable images from a very public life.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Camilla, Queen Consort of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III beside an ancient oak tree in Windsor Great Park in November.

item.title: What We Know About the Explosions Over the Kremlin
item.description: Moscow has accused Ukraine of a drone attack aimed at assassinating President Vladimir V. Putin, without providing evidence. Kyiv has strenuously denied involvement.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Russia accused Ukraine of attacking the Kremlin complex in Moscow with two drones on Wednesday. Ukraine has denied any involvement in the attack.

item.title: In The Hague, Zelensky Renews Call to Prosecute Russian War Crimes
item.description: As international support for an independent tribunal appears to be growing, the Ukrainian leader called for “true justice” for crimes in the war.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze and Victoria Kim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivering a speech in The Hague on Thursday.

item.title: Russia Accuses U.S. of Involvement in Explosions Over Kremlin
item.description: President Vladimir Putin’s spokesman claimed, without evidence, that the United States “dictated” Ukrainian strikes inside Russia. The White House quickly rejected the accusation.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Police officers in front of the Kremlin on the Red Square in Moscow on Wednesday.
